lexUnit.name: brood.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: think deeply about something that makes one unhappy.

sentence.text: I brooded constantly over why my being a girl rather than a boy would make my life so different from my brothers " .
The reception given by the best scientific circles to his quantum theory , now the basis of modern physics , caused Max Planck to brood darkly .
At times he would brood gloomily as he thought of the future course of the Reformation .
But Finn was no longer listening , brooding instead over his injured hand , his eyes veiled and murderous .
He wished Jane had not chosen this morning for a confrontation : she would be brooding now , and would be in a jagged mood by the time he arrived .
If criticism gets you down and you tend to brood , keeping one of these crystals near you is believed to bring you renewed confidence and a fresh perspective .
` Whereas Johnny made light of everything , " he has recalled , ` Keith brooded , rather old-maidish in his habits , on art and life in his voluminous notebooks .
He had brooded over his dead mother .
For hours he would brood over the significance of the case brought against Captain Bligh .

He became an encyclopaedia , a bore , a touchstone and a perennially reliable spring on the subject -- most of all he brooded over what Fletcher Christian might have done -- had he headed for Australia ?
He broods on how he lost the Parrot .
She was brooding about that when Ned came to her .
I know you 're unhappy , but you ca n't sit indoors and brood about it all day . "
It was no use brooding about it , but what else could she do ?
But Carrie brooded about it all the same .
I keep brooding about this morning 's telephone call to my agent .
I 've been brooding about that myself ever since I heard .
` You 're still brooding about Rosie , are n't you ? " he said .
One would construct alternative scenarios , and brood about them .
All that Sunday he had brooded on the episode in the cinema .
Ginny left him brooding on the past in front of a game show on television. ( 'Load of nonsense , " he always said about television ; nonetheless , he liked to have it on . )
They force the reader to slow down , to dwell or brood on what is happening .
You mean to say that you sit in this room all day , brooding on the memory of a dead film-star ?
Brooding on this severe prospect , MacDonald and his colleagues departed for their summer holidays .
In April Alex Trocchi , William Burroughs , Ken Kesey , Dan Richter , R.D. Laing , and stalwarts of the Anglo-American underground gathered to brood on the ` state of revolt " .
Since the debacle of the wedding/divorce he had become very morose , hardly responding to outside stimuli at all , sunk in his pain and brooding on his wrongs .
` Try not to brood on what you 've lost .
He brooded for a moment , sighed , and reached for the list again .
He had n't time to brood over it , for he had noticed something rather more disturbing ; access to the dock from the river was blocked .
Recession is biting at Softwright Systems , but Nick Durrant has no time to brood over it .
She was sitting miserably brooding when Marguerite tapped on her door and came in as Jenna invited her .
He passed the barred windows of Edwin 's studio ; the only light in the building came from an upstairs room , the living-room , where Beryl was almost certainly sitting and brooding alone .
Staring out of the carriage window at the dismal , wind-torn countryside , a plastic cup of weak British Rail coffee untouched in front of her , she brooded non-stop all the way to London .
